Let $AB$ be a line. Let $M,T$ be two points so that $M$ not lies on
$AB$, $T$ lies on $AB$, and $MT$ perpendicular to $AB$. Let $MD$ be any
other line who meets $AT$ in $D$.In a hyperbolic geometry, as $D$ moves
off to infinity along $AT$ the line $MD$ meets the line $MS$ which is
said to be parallel to $AT$. The angle $\widehat{SMT}$ is called the
*angle of parallelism* for perpendicular distance $d$, and is given by
$$P(d)=2\tan^{-1}(e^{-d}),$$ which is called *Lobachevsky’s formula.*
